AN EDITORIAL
We are happy to announce at this
time that, for the present at least,
the NEWS-LETTER will be able to continue publication twice each week as
the official newspaper of the University. A turnout of new men sufficiently large to warm the heart of
the most morose editor greeted our
announcement of last Tuesday. With
this injection of new blood into our
veins, we hope to make the paper
more healthy and stable than ever
before.

Upon reading your article of a

It is dedicated to those who have preceded us. Instead—what do we find?
Swaggering through with an air of

bumptious freshmen, indifferent sophomores, and self-satisfied juniors, all

painful to remain there for a while,
and to see this tradition usurped by

tradition and purpose of the Room.
To make it worse, adding insult to

enough, showing the same type of
breeding which is reflected in so
many ways in the actions of many
of the undergraduates.
It seems that this should absolutely not be allowed to continue, but how
to stop it? Certainly it takes more
than just a few persons.
It is too bad that this, one of the
few remaining traditions at the Hopkins, evidently is going the way of
all traditions, and will be thrown into
the waste-basket, to be completely
ignored.

Such meetings as professional
groups, students, engineering clubs,
etc., have heard addressess by the
candidate, who propounds the principles "production for use and not
for profit." Special appeals to the
brain workers as well as hand laborers have been made.
Dr. Mitchell has made many trips
throughout the State. During the
last few days, however, the campaign
has centered itself upon the city of
Baltimore and vicinity. In addition
to personal appearances, three broadcasts have been made by the Socialist candidate, the last of which was
Made last night.
Commenting upon Mrs. Bauernschrnidt's political stand, Dr. Mitchell said, "I lament the fact that Mrs.
Bauernschmidt has let herself be
dragged in to view the situation not
as it actually exists, but as other
hypocritical minds see it. She talks
Of Petty misdemeanors while the
gross misdemeanors are staring us
in the face. She refuses to open her
eyes to the real situation of unemployment which results in starvation,
crime, and its other all-too numerous
effects."

The Swarthmore Game

FROM THE BENCH

has been stated by Dr. Wilson Shaf-

Garnet Eleven On Defensive
For Most Of Game Cashes
In On Tallying Chances

Kicking Excellent
Reynolds Repulses Rivals Repeatedly With Lengthy
Punts; Aided By Pasarew
By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG
For the fourth consecutive time
the Blue Jay eleven demonstrated conclusively that the ball game does not
necessarily go to the team which piles
up the most yardage and first downs.
The latest bit of proof came at
Swarthmore last Saturday, when the
Garnet host, on the defensive for the
greater part of the afternoon,
emerged from the struggle with a
well-earned 12-0 triumph.
Three weeks ago Hopkins held the
upper hand over Lehigh for threefourths of the battle, only to succumb
by a 7-6 margin. The following Saturday the Jays bowed to Washington
College, 13-0, although amassing 15
first downs to the visitors' 8. The
tables were reversed at Haverford,
however, when the Black and Blue
was outgained almost 2 to 1, and yet
romped off the field sport'ing a 6-0
victory.

IN THE LOW 80'S!

sent the ball far out of the Hopkins area.—The Sun, __Sunday

Cross-Country Team To
23-32 Win In The South
Realizing at last an ambition fostered for three years, the Johns Hopkins cross-country team defeated Virginia 23-32 last Saturday. The meet
was held on the Cavaliers' course,
which was unusually hilly and provided a stiff test for the competing
harriers.

to victory, winning in the time of

Reynolds, Pasarew Excel
From this point on, excepting a
few minutes in the third quarter,
Hopkins was distinctly the aggressor,
being materially aided by Pete Reynolds' booting. Repeatedly the Jay
halfback spiraled 50-yard punts into
the ozone to set the enemy back on
its heels. Rube Pasarew teamed perfectly with Reynolds on these kicks,
either nipping the Swarthmore safety in his tracks or downing the ball
himself.
Swarthmore's second touchdown
came at the close of the third period
and climaxed a sustained drive of
50 yards. At one point in this march
the Garnets were repulsed for three
downs and forced to kick, but a 15yard penalty called against Hopkins
on the play sent the victors on their
way once again. This time they were
not to be denied, Spruance smashing
over from the 1-foot line.
Shift In Backfield
One noticeable change in Coach
Van Orman's backfield plans was
Reynolds' succession to the .triplethreat berth hitherto occupied by McClean. Pete did all of the kicking
and most of the tossing, with McClean smashing the line on the
power plays, as well as running interference and performing sensationally on defense.
The Jay secondary used a short,
running lateral on numerous occasions, but for the most part it failed
to net any appreciable yardage.

by Paul Kaiss, former mentor at

attended that school and later participated at Baltimore. He is a member of the local bar association.

time that, for the present at least,
the NEWS-LETTER will be able to continue publication twice each week as
the official newspaper of the University. A turnout of new men sufficiently large to warm the heart of

announcement of last Tuesday. With
this injection of new blood into our
veins, we hope to make the paper
more healthy and stable than ever
before.

Dear Mr. Kemler:
We are veteran readers of the
NEWS-LETTER, rather from necessity
than choice. We find it twice weekly
in our boxes, and, at odd moments,
read its columns. We have, in the
course of our perusals of the paper,
come upon your articles. Mr. Kemler,
we are puzzled.
Upon reading your article of a
week ago, "A Cad Among the Gods",
we were caught in an intellectual
Sargasso Sea, entwined among green
of devilish intent — and
weed
promptly sank to the muddy bottom.
Coming up about Wednesday of
this week, we rested comfortably until today. We have just finished your
piece entitled "You Can't Print That",
and are now writing this from the
bottom, having precipitously sunk
again upon reading it.
The reason for this is clear in our
own minds. We plead ignorance;
blind, uncouth ignorance. We are at
a loss to understand your words.
They choke us, stifle us. And yet we
are convinced that, by the haughty
tone of your writing, you must have
something to say. Our only plea is, as
we wallow on the bottom, that you
make yourself clear, stoop to the
level of the poor boobi americani,
grant them the pleasure of understanding your mighty thoughts. 0!
Prophet, speak simply that we may
learn! Grant us your wisdom in small
doses. Let us partake of your knowledge, so that the truth may make us

who want to be quiet for a little time.
It is dedicated to those who have preceded us. Instead—what do we find?
Swaggering through with an air of
nonchalance and self-sufficiency, all
those who should remain outside—
bumptious freshmen, indifferent sophomores, and self-satisfied juniors, all
of whom pervade its sanctity with the
air that the Room is for all to enjoy,
and that they have just as much
right there as anybody else. It is
painful to remain there for a while,
and to see this tradition usurped by
a large number of those that pass
through, seemingly oblivious of the
tradition and purpose of the Room.
To make it worse, adding insult to
injury, some of the aforementioned interlopers do not take the trouble to
remove their hats, in itself bad
enough, showing the same type of
breeding which is reflected in so
many ways in the actions of many
of the undergraduates.
It seems that this should absolutely not be allowed to continue, but how
to stop it? Certainly it takes more
than just a few persons.
It is too bad that this, one of the
few remaining traditions at the Hopkins, evidently is going the way of
all traditions, and will be thrown into
the waste-basket, to be completely
ignored.

Specified that only one meal could be
served the first year men on openhouse days, leaving it up to the various fraternities whether that meal
should be luncheon or dinner. No organized parties of any kind can be
Sponsored by fraternities on the
Board, with the exception of openhouse affairs, according to this year's

midnight on Saturday, November 17,

Of any kind can pass between fraternity men and men in their first
Year of residence at the University.
After bids are presented at 3 p. m.,
on November 18, unrestricted rushing is permitted.

Meets Real Issues

Such meetings as professional
groups, students, engineering clubs,
etc., have heard addressess by the
candidate, who propounds the principles "production for use and not
for profit." Special appeals to the
brain workers as well as hand laborers have been made.
Dr. Mitchell has made many trips
throughout the State. During the
last few days, however, the campaign
has centered itself upon the city of
Baltimore and vicinity. In addition
to personal appearances, three broadcasts have been made by the Socialist candidate, the last of which was
Made last night.
Commenting upon Mrs. Bauernschrnidt's political stand, Dr. Mitchell said, "I lament the fact that Mrs.
Bauernschmidt has let herself be
dragged in to view the situation not
as it actually exists, but as other
hypocritical minds see it. She talks
Of Petty misdemeanors while the
gross misdemeanors are staring us
in the face. She refuses to open her
eyes to the real situation of unemployment which results in starvation,
crime, and its other all-too numerous
effects."

FROM THE BENCH

has been stated by Dr. Wilson Shaf-

Garnet Eleven On Defensive
For Most Of Game Cashes
In On Tallying Chances

Kicking Excellent
Reynolds Repulses Rivals Repeatedly With Lengthy
Punts; Aided By Pasarew
By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG
For the fourth consecutive time
the Blue Jay eleven demonstrated conclusively that the ball game does not
necessarily go to the team which piles
up the most yardage and first downs.
The latest bit of proof came at
Swarthmore last Saturday, when the
Garnet host, on the defensive for the
greater part of the afternoon,
emerged from the struggle with a
well-earned 12-0 triumph.
Three weeks ago Hopkins held the
upper hand over Lehigh for threefourths of the battle, only to succumb
by a 7-6 margin. The following Saturday the Jays bowed to Washington
College, 13-0, although amassing 15
first downs to the visitors' 8. The
tables were reversed at Haverford,
however, when the Black and Blue
was outgained almost 2 to 1, and yet
romped off the field sport'ing a 6-0
victory.

IN THE LOW 80'S!
Pete Reynolds, Hopkins halfback, was one of the game's top
performers, by virtue of his putting, which on several occasions
sent the ball far out of the Hopkins area.—The Sun, __Sunday
morning, November 4.

Open Season With

Holtzman And Sholtes Lead
Cross-Country Team To

Realizing at last an ambition fostered for three years, the Johns Hopkins cross-country team defeated Virginia 23-32 last Saturday. The meet
was held on the Cavaliers' course,
which was unusually hilly and provided a stiff test for the competing
harriers.

to victory, winning in the time of

Reynolds, Pasarew Excel
From this point on, excepting a
few minutes in the third quarter,
Hopkins was distinctly the aggressor,
being materially aided by Pete Reynolds' booting. Repeatedly the Jay
halfback spiraled 50-yard punts into
the ozone to set the enemy back on
its heels. Rube Pasarew teamed perfectly with Reynolds on these kicks,
either nipping the Swarthmore safety in his tracks or downing the ball
himself.
Swarthmore's second touchdown
came at the close of the third period
and climaxed a sustained drive of
50 yards. At one point in this march
the Garnets were repulsed for three
downs and forced to kick, but a 15yard penalty called against Hopkins
on the play sent the victors on their
way once again. This time they were
not to be denied, Spruance smashing
over from the 1-foot line.
Shift In Backfield
One noticeable change in Coach
Van Orman's backfield plans was
Reynolds' succession to the .triplethreat berth hitherto occupied by McClean. Pete did all of the kicking
and most of the tossing, with McClean smashing the line on the
power plays, as well as running interference and performing sensationally on defense.
The Jay secondary used a short,
running lateral on numerous occasions, but for the most part it failed
to net any appreciable yardage.

Schedule Being Arranged
To Include Matches With

Fencing, youngest of Hopkins varsity sports, is looking forward to
a big year. The actual participation in
varsity competition will not ;begin
until after the first of the year when
the Blue Jay fencers will pti.)bably
meet the University of Delaware.
A schedule of varsity competition
is being worked out now and when
complete
will
probably
include
matches with Haverford, Temple, Lehigh, Massachusetts Tech, and Notre
Da me.
The fencing team is being coached
by Paul Kaiss, former mentor at
both the Baltimore City College and
Baltimore University. Kaiss was captain of City College's team when he
attended that school and later participated at Baltimore. He is a member of the local bar association.
